item.title: FDA Approves First Alzheimer's Drug to Treat Underlying Cause
item.description: Yesterday, the FDA approved Biogen's aducanumab, the first drug to treat the underlying cause of Alzheimer's (sticky brain plaques) and potentially slow the disease's progression in early stage patients. There's certainly money to be made: Biogen says the treatment, which will be sold under the name “Aduhelm,” will cost $56,000 a year.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Apple Unveils New Privacy and Work Features at WWDC
item.description: If Apple loses, the company may have to rewrite the rules of its money-printing App Store. Yesterday, Apple defended itself and said the App Store has paid over $230 billion to developers since opening in 2008. Apple kicked off its annual WWDC conference for developers with a keynote address showing off its new software features. Apple users will be able to block tracking by email senders, a change that could mean big disruptions for businesses that depend on email marketing. And trusted contacts to get you back into iCloud after you forget your new password. Fancier maps.

item.title: El Salvador Move to Adopt Bitcoin as Legal Tender
item.description: Why El Salvador? On Saturday, El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, said he’s going to send a bill to the legislature to make bitcoin a legal tender in the country. It’d be the first country to formally adopt the cryptocurrency as part of its economy.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: G-7 Ministers Agree to Corporate Minimum Tax
item.description: The Biden administration estimates a global minimum tax system would lead to $500 billion in additional tax revenue for the US over the next decade.  The provision is meant to address European leaders’ concerns that they can’t sufficiently tax tech giants like Facebook and Google, because while those companies make tons of money in Europe, they are based in the US and pay taxes there.   The backstory: Multinational companies have been taking advantage of existing tax rules by shuffling money between jurisdictions with super-low rates.

item.title: Facebook Extends President Trump’s Ban For Two More Years
item.description: Zoom out: Trump’s blog’s failure is a reminder that social platforms like Facebook don’t just offer a place to share snarky opinions, but also an algorithm-amplified megaphone. Facebook had kept a special list of politicians who were allowed to bend its content moderation rules because their opinions were considered “newsworthy content that should, as a general rule, be seen and heard,” Facebook VP of Global Affairs Nick Clegg said in 2019.

item.title: Icebreakers with… Uma Valeti
item.description: The company raised $161 million in Series B funding, which included investments from SoftBank Group, Bill Gates, Richard Branson, and Tyson Foods. Now for the last five years, I've been eating it again. The other thing to know is when to go fast and when to go slow. Now his company Upside Foods (previously Memphis Meats) is doing just that: growing real meat in a lab. But I made a promise to myself that I will only eat the meat that we produce.  No. I grew up in a meat-eating family, but during medical school, I stopped eating meat because I thought, "I don't like how meat is coming to the table." So that meant in the last five years, building the company up slowly so people would understand what we're trying to do. Absolutely don't look back because it looks scary if you start looking back. You can go fast on a lot of things, but you have to deliberately slow down for some really important moments. What's your favorite meal made out of Upside Foods's cell-grown meat?
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Paul vs. Mayweather: But...Why?
item.description: Logan Paul, the social media star, will fight Floyd Mayweather Jr., considered one of the best boxers ever, in an exhibition match. If you are one of the many people who decide to watch (it'll likely be one of the most-viewed events of the year), you will probably not see a competitive fight. Paul, who only recently got into boxing, is 0–1 in his career. Paul's often been on the wrong side of law and order. My goal is to be the biggest entertainer on the planet. We don't know how much Logan will make from the match, but it's going to be a lot—Mayweather is poised to make $102 million tonight, according to The Sun.Bottom line: In the end, what Mayweather and the Paul brothers are really fighting for is our eyeballs.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Make It Work: Returning to the Office and Bad Management
item.description: How do we have a conversation with leadership about this?” I'm not sure what type of treatment you received from management, but if it was not aligned with general ethics or company policy then it should be reported. Ya know, Dan, if this is something you are still thinking about then you can reach out to your former employer and let them know how you feel.  “Did I do a disservice to fellow employees and management when I didn't disclose that the reason I left my company was due to my treatment by management?” With the collective, you can reach out to HR through email; in that email, you can make a request to have a group session to discuss the new rule. Ask Kate here.

item.description: The promise of supersonic commercial flight reemerged yesterday when United Airlines announced it's buying 15 jets from Boom Supersonic.  Now, Boom and other supersonic startups are working on net-zero emissions and noise-muffling tech. Supersonic = faster than the speed of sound.  Looking ahead...
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: California Drought Could Cause Wide-Ranging Industry Problems
item.description: The state of play: California Gov. Gavin Newsom has put 41 counties under a state of emergency in an attempt to drastically limit water use. Some scientists say the region is facing the worst drought in centuries. Officials are predicting the water level of Lake Oroville, the Beyoncé of California lakes, to hit a record low in August. California accounts for 80% of the US' almond supply, but because of shrinking water allocations, some farmers are simply bulldozing those notoriously thirsty almond trees. Anyone who dislikes wildfires.
